Massachusetts General Laws chapter 186,.proposition: The Plaintiff, Jessica Moore, brings this complaint against her landlord, Defendant Karen Thompson, for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts General Laws chapter 186, section 14, and related violations of her landlord-tenant rights.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19,.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, as the amount in controversy falls within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1,.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, because the events giving rise to this complaint occurred in Lowell, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14,.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, every residential lease in Massachusetts includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, which prohibits a landlord from interfering with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of the rental property.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7 127L;.proposition: Landlords are responsible for repairing and maintaining rental units to ensure habitable conditions and compliance with the state sanitary code.

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.proposition: Landlords are responsible for repairing and maintaining rental units to ensure habitable conditions and compliance with the state sanitary code.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.support_reasoning: The opinion directly grounds the implied warranty of habitability in the landlord’s duty to deliver and maintain premises in habitable condition, measured at least by compliance with the State Sanitary Code. It affirms that the tenant’s obligation to pay rent is conditioned on the landlord’s ongoing obligation to maintain habitability, and explicitly notes that the Sanitary Code imposes on landlords a duty to maintain apartments in habitable condition. Thus, it supports the proposition that landlords are responsible for repairs and maintenance necessary to keep rental units habitable and code-compliant.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.relevant_excerpt: “[A] lease is essentially a contract between the landlord and the tenant wherein the landlord promises to deliver and maintain the demised premises in habitable condition and the tenant promises to pay rent for such habitable premises. These promises constitute interdependent and mutual considerations. Thus, the tenant’s obligation to pay rent is predicated on the landlord’s obligation to deliver and maintain the premises in habitable condition.” … “For example, the State Sanitary Code… imposed on the landlord a duty to maintain an apartment in habitable condition….”

*Castenholz v. Caira*, 21 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts has held that “[i]nterference with a tenant’s rights need not be willful for a landlord to breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment.” *Castenholz v. Caira*, 21 Mass. App. Ct. 758, 763 (1986).
*Castenholz v. Caira*, 21 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The proposition concerns the covenant of quiet enjoyment and whether interference must be willful. Castenholz v. Caira is a Massachusetts Appeals Court decision about statutory remedies for mishandling a residential security deposit under G.L. c. 186, § 15B; it does not discuss the covenant of quiet enjoyment or the willfulness requirement at all. It therefore cannot be authority for the quoted proposition attributed to the Supreme Judicial Court about quiet enjoyment.
*Castenholz v. Caira*, 21 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Section 15B, as thus construed, is not a minefield of potential multiple penalties for a landlord who makes an innocent mistake. Any one of the violations of duty listed in subsection (6) will entitle the tenant to immediate return of his entire deposit on request, regardless of whether the violation was innocent or wilful. Mellor v. Berman, 390 Mass. at 281-283.”

*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855, 873.proposition: The presence of mold, which poses a health risk, has been held to constitute a violation of health, safety, and sanitary standards under Massachusetts law.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855, 873.support_reasoning: The opinion in Haddad v. Gonzalez discusses numerous serious defects in the apartment and building (lack of heat, hazardous floors, infestation with cockroaches and rodents, missing windows, etc.) as violations of the State Sanitary Code and of the implied warranty of habitability. However, it does not mention mold at all, nor does it analyze mold-related health risks or classify mold as a violation of health, safety, or sanitary standards. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the specific proposition about mold under Massachusetts law.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855, 873.relevant_excerpt: “After his view, the judge made express findings. Among other defects, the judge found that: (1) there was no functioning heating system; (2) several basement windows were missing; (3) the apartment windows were in deplorable condition and without screens; (4) ceiling fixtures were missing; (5) the walls and ceilings were cracked and had holes; (6) doors were missing knobs; (7) the flooring in places was hazardous; and (8) the apartment was infested with cockroaches and rodents.”

105 CMR 410.000 et seq..proposition: The Massachusetts sanitary code, 105 CMR 410.000 et seq., requires landlords to ensure that bathrooms are adequately ventilated to prevent the type of moisture buildup that fosters mold growth.

*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The Massachusetts sanitary code, 105 CMR 410.000 et seq., requires landlords to ensure that bathrooms are adequately ventilated to prevent the type of moisture buildup that fosters mold growth. See *Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987).
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion mentions several State Sanitary Code violations generally but does not discuss bathroom ventilation, moisture, or mold, nor does it interpret 105 CMR 410.000 as imposing a duty specifically regarding bathroom ventilation to prevent mold. The only portion of the opinion that substantively interprets the sanitary code concerns written agreements for heat and hot water, not ventilation requirements. Thus, this case does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Several violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1983), have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property. The violations include the existence of lead paint, cracked windows, missing window screens, stained ceiling, loose bathroom tiles, mice, ants, missing balustrades on the porches, inadequate trash receptables, and inadequate door locks.”

*College Hill Properties, LLC v. Fiorent.raw_text: *College Hill Properties, LLC v. Fiorentino*, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 378, 383-84 (2016).
*College Hill Properties, LLC v. Fiorent.proposition: The Plaintiff has a right to recover damages for the mold’s interference with her enjoyment of the leased premises, including actual damages, emotional distress, and personal property damage.
*College Hill Properties, LLC v. Fiorent.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is Santana v. Commonwealth concerning eligibility to sue under the Massachusetts erroneous conviction statute, not College Hill Properties v. Fiorentino, and it does not address landlord-tenant damages, mold, interference with enjoyment, or recovery for emotional distress or property damage. The case focuses exclusively on procedural and substantive standards for wrongful conviction claims. It therefore does not support the stated proposition about a tenant’s right to recover mold-related damages.
*College Hill Properties, LLC v. Fiorent.relevant_excerpt: “The erroneous conviction statute, G. L. c. 258D, §§ 1-9, represents a limited waiver of the Commonwealth's sovereign immunity so as to permit eligible persons who were wrongfully convicted and imprisoned to file a civil action in the Superior Court and to pursue remedies including recovery of up to $500,000 in damages.”

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 101 (1.proposition: Emotional distress and health-related injuries caused by a landlord’s breach are compensable in actions for breach of quiet enjoyment.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 101 (1.support_reasoning: The court reads G.L. c. 186, § 14’s “actual and consequential damages” language for interference with quiet enjoyment to include all reasonably foreseeable losses, expressly noting this covers personal as well as economic injuries. It then applies that interpretation to hold that the tenant’s emotional distress and resulting personal injuries from the landlord’s failure to maintain sanitary, habitable conditions fall within the scope of compensable damages under the quiet-enjoyment statute, even though the separate quiet-enjoyment verdict was vacated as duplicative. This directly supports that emotional and health-related injuries are compensable in actions for breach of quiet enjoyment.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 101 (1.relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 provides that tenants may recover ‘actual and consequential’ damages from landlords who have interfered with their quiet enjoyment of leased premises. … Generally, ‘actual damages’ are losses flowing directly from a wrongful act. ‘Consequential damages’ cover all losses that are reasonably foreseeable to the actor, even if they do not result inevitably from the act complained of. … The combination in § 14 of both actual and consequential damages, therefore, suggests that the Legislature intended to include all reasonably foreseeable losses — personal as well as economic — within the scope of statutory recovery. In the present case, not only were Solomon’s injuries foreseeable, but the jury found specifically that Gem knew or should have known that if it permitted floods to occur, Solomon would suffer emotional harm.”
